Learn about partition key (PK) and sort: Learn about partition key (PK) and sort key (SK) design patterns for DynamoDB.
This guide explains how to design partit: This guide explains how to design partition keys (PK) and sort keys (SK) for your entities in DynamoDB. Proper key design is critical for performance, scalability, and query efficiency.
Use this guide when you need to:: Use this guide when you need to:
Design keys for a new entity type: Design keys for a new entity type
Enable efficient query patterns (list by: Enable efficient query patterns (list by tenant, filter by date)

Include tenant code in PK for partition-: Include tenant code in PK for partition-level isolation
Can't list child items without knowing a: Can't list child items without knowing all keys
Use shared PK with different SK prefixes: Use shared PK with different SK prefixes
IDs are not sortable by creation time: IDs are not sortable by creation time
Use ULID which is both unique and time-s: Use ULID which is both unique and time-sortable
Version suffix in SK enables optimistic: Version suffix in SK enables optimistic locking

Scenario: Store products that belong to: Scenario: Store products that belong to a tenant with unique IDs.
When to use: Standalone entities without: When to use: Standalone entities without parent-child relationships.
Use Case: Order with Line Items: Use Case: Order with Line Items
Scenario: An order contains multiple ite: Scenario: An order contains multiple items. Need to query all items for an order efficiently.
Solution: Share PK between parent and ch: Solution: Share PK between parent and children, use SK prefix to distinguish item types.
Pattern 3: User with Multiple Auth Provi: Pattern 3: User with Multiple Auth Providers
Scenario: Users can sign in with local p: Scenario: Users can sign in with local password, SSO, or OAuth. Need to link all auth methods to one user.
Solution: Same PK for all user records,: Solution: Same PK for all user records, SK prefix indicates authentication provider.
Use Case: User Belongs to Multiple Organ: Use Case: User Belongs to Multiple Organizations
Scenario: In a SaaS application, one use: Scenario: In a SaaS application, one user can belong to multiple tenants/organizations.
Solution: Use a common tenant with SK th: Solution: Use a common tenant with SK that combines tenant and user codes.
Use Case: Application Settings and Confi: Use Case: Application Settings and Configuration
Scenario: Store email templates, product: Scenario: Store email templates, product categories, and application settings.
Solution: Use type prefix (SETTING, DATA: Solution: Use type prefix (SETTING, DATA) in SK to organize different configuration types.
Use Case: Activity Logs and Audit Trail: Use Case: Activity Logs and Audit Trail
Scenario: Store time-stamped events that: Scenario: Store time-stamped events that need to be queried by date range.
Solution: Include date in PK for time-ba: Solution: Include date in PK for time-based partitioning, timestamp in SK for sorting.
